Award.AwardTitle: Transcribed Microsatellites as Engines of Adaptive Change; Testing the "Tuning Knob" Hypothesis in Natural Populations of the Annual Sunflower, Helianthus annuus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Microsatellites are highly repetitive DNA sequences found throughout organismal genomes. These sequences have very high mutation rates that change the physical length of the microsatellite. After they were first discovered, it was assumed that microsatellites would only be found in nonfunctional regions of genomes because they would likely disrupt normal gene function. In fact, some of the earliest microsatellites described are known to cause neurodegenerative diseases, like Huntington's chorea. However, we now know that many thousands of genes in many species include microsatellites. The prevalence of microsatellites in genes implies that many may be functional. This project focuses on the role microsatellites might play in altering how genes are expressed in sunflowers. The researchers are testing the hypothesis that microsatellite mutations alter gene expression levels in sunflowers, suggesting that this class of microsatellite can facilitate evolutionary change. Given their mutation rates, microsatellites may represent the most rapidly evolving gene regulatory elements in genomes. If this hypothesis is true, then microsatellite lengths should correlate with gene expression levels. Further, if selection is acting on this source of variation, then allele frequencies in natural populations should reflect these processes. Acceptance of these mechanisms would suggest that populations acquire novel and heritable variation at rates much higher than typically assumed.

Broader Impacts: This project supports undergraduate student researchers. Senior researchers will expose biology students to advanced computational methods, and computer science majors interested in computational biology will be involved in the collection of data and analysis. In addition, a major focus of student training is the development of their grant writing and data analysis skills, and the presentation of scientific research findings. Students will present their findings at scientific meetings and coauthor research journal articles. Further, Mississippi State University has one of the highest percentages of minorities among research universities in the country, and strategies designed to include minorities in this project are being pursued.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

Microsatellites are small repetitive sequences of DNA with exceptionally high mutation rates that are common in most organisms including plants and animals. Science was surprised to find that microsatellites frequently occur within genes rather than being restricted to nonfunctional regions of genomes. Their common occurrence in genes suggests microsatellites may play functional roles, or at least have the capacity to influence gene function and organismal traits. Unlike most mutations where a single nucleotide is simply substituted, microsatellite mutations result in new alleles that are slightly longer or shorter than the parent allele. As a result, these regions of genomes expand and contract. This characteristic of microsatellites led to the “tuning knob” hypothesis that suggests these expansions and contractions correlate with minor increases or decreases of trait values dependent on the genes where microsatellites are found. The research supported through this grant explores the role microsatellites might play in regulating genes. The distribution of different classes of microsatellites in expressed regions of the sunflower genome was characterized. This work showed that only particular types of microsatellites were common in specific classes of genes. An intriguing finding from this study was that microsatellites are more common in genes regulating the response of plants to environmental stress. This is interesting because it is consistent with microsatellites facilitating rapid evolutionary change in response to a changing environment. Further, many of the microsatellites in genes reveal patterns in allele frequencies across populations consistent with selection favoring certain alleles in certain populations. Other work has revealed that genes expressed at different levels in different populations are enriched with specific classes of microsatellites. Perhaps most critical is that this study provides evidence that microsatellite allele length is correlated with gene regulation at hundreds of genes in and among populations of sunflowers. This provides really direct support for the tuning knob hypothesis. Additional work to explore the relationship between many of these newly characterized microsatellites is now being conducted to determine whether selection acts on these microsatellites directly, and whether different alleles and patterns of gene regulation across a broader latitudinal gradient with more extreme variation in environmental conditions.

Broader Impacts

All of the work described provided training and research opportunities to numerous undergraduates from Mississippi State University as well as summer research opportunities for visiting students enrolled elsewhere. The majority of these students are from groups underrepresented in science. Further, the success of these students following their time on this project bears special mention. The Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality hired one female student while another female student from Puerto Rico is studying dentistry. Yet another student supported by this grant is putting many of the computer programming skills she learned in the lab to use at her new job for Intel. She is also working toward a MS degree at the University of Southern California. Aside from supporting undergraduates working on the sunflower project, the grant was designed to facilitate undergraduate research throughout the laboratory. Two African American students that conducted research in the lab have gone on to seek advanced degrees. Another student has since published her undergraduate research project as first author in a peer reviewed journal. That student is now working toward a PhD at Iowa State University. In addition to undergraduates, the grant provided training opportunities for a student that had completed a MS at Mississippi State University as a Research Technician. He is now working toward a PhD at Ohio State University. A Postdoctoral Researcher that worked on the project now works as a plant genomics expert for Eurofins.

Aside from training opportunities this project might encourage numerous potential applications for microsatellites as tuning knobs. For example, the work described here suggests that microsatellites may allow plant breeders to develop crops that are better able to grow in a broader range of environmental conditions.
